title: Conductors - three spheres in successive contact

content.question: Three conducting spheres each have charge <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mstyle></math>. Spheres <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> have the same radius, while Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a larger radius. Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is brought in contact with Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the two spheres come to equilibrium, and then they are separated. Next, Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is brought in contact with sphere <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, the two spheres come to equilibrium, and then they are separated. Which of the following correctly compares the electric potential <math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math> at the surface of each sphere at the end of the described procedure?

choices.label: <math alttext="V sub 1 equals V sub 2, which equals V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="V sub 1 equals V sub 3, which is greater than V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="V sub 2 equals V sub 3, which is greater than V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="V sub 2 is greater than V sub 3, which is greater than V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="V sub 2 equals V sub 3, which is greater than V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
